column3: when you want to tell somebody to do or not to do something
column4:
V (Come here. Have a chocolate)
or
don't + V (Don't fall. Don't go)

column3: when you want people to do or not do things with you
column4:
Let's + V (Let's go)
or
Let's + not + V (Let's not have fish)
Let's = Let us
column5: Unit 35 Do this! Don’t do that! Let’s do this!

column4:
We can start sentence with there is without previous knowledge of the thing we are going to talk about (There's a book on the table)

Before using it is we should say about this thing in previous sentence or previous part of the same sentence (I like this book. It’s interesting.)
column5: Unit 37 there is there are

column4:
am/is/are + being + V3 (+ by ...)
The office is being cleaned at the moment

the meaning

column3: Can we say 'I use to ...' for the present?
column4: No. We use <b>used to ...<b> only for the past

column3: action in the past that has connection with now
column4: present perfect - I've lost my key. I don't have it

column3: action in the past that no longer true now
column4: past simple - I lost my key yesterday. But now I have it

column3: talking about a period of time that continues from the past until now (Something that may be considered as an achievement)
column4: present perfect. (Have you ever) been to ... = visited

column3: talking about things that happened or didn't happen in someone's life but without connection to particular time
column4: present perfect. Have you seen this movie?

column3: talking about things that lasted some time until now
column4: present perfect. How long have you been married?

column3: tense if there is no time marker at all
column4: probably present perfect. I have lost my key. Have you seen Kate?

column3: modal verb to say what you think is necessary, when you give your opinion

Do you like tea? = Do you think tea is nice?
